thread.title: VOM FASS owner offers insight into business, personal life
thread.title_full: VOM FASS owner offers insight into business, personal life | www.statesman.com

title: VOM FASS owner offers insight into business, personal life
text:
Name: Chris Vetromile
Age and place of birth: 41, Greenbrae, Calif.; lived there only until I was 18. I graduated high school from Memorial High School in Houston.
Immediate family: Kristin Vetromile, who works at the shop most mornings then is the best mom the rest of the day; Logan Vetromile, age 6 and first-grader at Forest Trail Elementary, and Liam Vetromile, age 4 and preschooler at St. John Neumann Catholic Church.
Chris Vetromile Education: Bachelor of Science in environmental (civil) engineering from the University of Southern California.
Occupation: Owner/operator of VOM FASS Oils, Vinegars, Spirits & Wine at 2785 Bee Cave Road. VomFassAustin.com.
What’s your career ambition? Open at least two more VOM FASS shops in and around the Austin area.
Civic or other nonprofit activities: I love to coach my boys’ sports teams.
What’s your idea of the ideal vacation? Any mountain resort for a day of skiing after 6 feet of fresh powder fell the night before. Just ask my wife: “No friends on powder days.”
What is the latest project in which you are involved? I am on the Marketing Committee for National VOM FASS. We are starting a huge campaign push to get the VOM FASS logo as recognizable as the golden arches.
What is your favorite business in the Westbank? VOM FASS, of course. No seriously, Marye’s Gourmet Pizza has the best pies in town using fresh organic local products.
Hobbies: Hunting, fishing, skiing and scuba diving with my wife and boys.
What qualities in people draw you to be their friend? People who are loyal, trustworthy and generally have a great outlook on life.
I have a knack for: Cooking and using all the products from VOM FASS to come up with new and flavorful dishes.
The one thing I’d like to change about the Westbank is: The traffic. I know it is on the way in West Lake, but 360 needs some help.
Most significant or interesting job: Most interesting job was working in the oil field in Africa, but the most significant is being a father to my boys, someone I hope they will always be proud to look up to.
My pet peeve is: Directed toward my children, whining. There is always a better way to solve a situation than whining.
Most exciting or dangerous thing I’ve ever done: That’s a toss-up between climbing Kilimanjaro, Africa, with my brother or skydiving with my wife in Monterey Bay, California.
Life’s most challenging endeavor is: Running a new startup business, VOM FASS, and raising a young family at the same time. Both have been challenging and rewarding.
What is the last book you read? “Killing Jesus: A History” by Bill O’Reilly.
If you were stranded on an uninhabited island, with no means of communication or escape, what is one thing that you would you like to have? My wife. She would build our shelter, while I fish for food.
Is there anything that you passed up on doing that you now regret? Having children earlier in life. It has been the best accomplishment on my long resume.
How would you like to be remembered? As a great dad and a wonderful husband.
